page.title: 01Broadhembury-North Hill
page.content: Chief feature-North Hill, a ridge of the Blackdown Hills which rises steeply (very steeply near the top). It is on 'greensand', is very boggy. On top of North Hill is a very large open plateau used as a Gliding Club. On the west slope is a Rifle Range, which ends at the 'common land'. This goes from the bog to the top of the hill, and is dotted which old Whetstone pits and holes from which, earlier in the century, road stone was taken. The block contains no villages (only half of Kerswell, a hamlet of 36 or so houses), but one of the village's working farms comes within this area. There are about ten largish farms with a cottage or two and a main farm house. Farming is mainly dairy-with-cereal-and/or roots or sheep-and-pigs-with-roots. chickens kept are mostly for local use
